awd_titl_txt: CIF: Small: Collaborative Research: Fundamental Limits of Information Systems: A Computational Approach
awd_abstract_narration:
Information theory provides a general framework in which the fundamental limits of information systems (wired and wireless networks, cryptographic systems, data compression and storage systems, and others) can be meaningfully investigated. The investigation of such limits is traditionally conducted analytically, requiring in many cases substantial ingenuity. As modern information systems become more and more complex, such an approach becomes rather unwieldy. The main goal of this project is to build upon initial successes in applying a computational approach to characterize the fundamental limits of certain distributed storage systems, and to further understand what it takes for the proposed computational approach to be successful in the broad setting of big-data infrastructure.

The proposed computational approach is built upon the vantage point that the overall process of identifying and proving fundamental limits can be alternatively viewed as an optimization problem under the specific constraints of the system at hand and the general constraints of information measures. The difficulty lies in the fact that such optimization programs are usually very large for any practically relevant problems, and numerical results are difficult to interpret. This project pursues three major thrusts: 1) finding more efficient problem representations using symmetry and other constraints; 2) improving the optimization algorithms using domain knowledge; and 3) finding intelligent interpretations of the computed results through duality to facilitate engineering design. The results are expected to have measurable impacts on the following two disciplines: 1) Big-data infrastructure: The ongoing big-data movement calls for information systems with diverse reliability and functionality requirements. By identifying the fundamental limits of such systems, accurate performance evaluations and meaningful design guidelines may be assessed; and 2) Information theory: The proposed study will bridge the disciplines of computational optimization and information theory, and instill more computerized intelligence into information theory research.

por.por_cntn:
This project proposed a computational approach for characterizing the fundamental performance limits of complex information systems.  As modern information systems become more and more complex, the conventional approach of establishing such limits analytically becomes rather unwieldy, and in many cases, it is questionable whether it is in fact at a level that is humanly manageable. The logical steps of the proposed approach are to first use numerical optimization techniques to identify key combinatorial structures, which will then be used to construct precise analytical solutions to the general problems.

As an important test case, the proposed approach was applied to several exact-repair regenerating code problems. The technical results obtained have helped to gain definitive structural insights on how to achieve the optimal tradeoffs between the node capacity and repair bandwidth, especially at the Minimum-Bandwidth Repair (MBR) point. These insights provide useful guidelines for designing efficient and secure distributed storage systems with multilevel node-fail proof capabilities. The combinatorial structures identified by the proposed computational approach are very compact, suggesting that they might be useful for solving some other regenerating coding problems as well. The obtained results have been disseminated through journal and conference publications.

This project has helped to support one graduate student, Shuo Shao, for completing his Ph.D. degree in Electrical Engineering at Texas A&M. Upon graduation, Mr. Shao joined the Shanghai Jiao Tong University (SJTU) as an Assistant Professor in Electrical Engineering. This project has also helped to support the PI’s research at Texas A&M. Part of the research results has been broadly disseminated via the PI’s graduate course offering on information theory.
